Having found help for Cedric from the hermit, Graham decides it would be best to sail there rather than risk hurting him further by carrying him.

Graham notices a small hole in the bottom of the old sailboat.
Cedric quietly moans from the bottom of the boat.
Graham is not strong enough to push the boat.

A large beast rushes toward Graham with hatred in his red-rimmed eyes.
A large beast lies stunned on the floor.

Mordack lies asleep on his huge, horrendous bed.
The cat is attracted to the fish.

The cat seems content after eating the fish.
The cat looks in a hurry to leave.
The cat struggles in vain inside the bag.

Graham could never overpower this huge beast!
Graham wants no part of this beast!
This would not be a good time to bother Mordack!
It wouldn't be wise for Graham to carry the cat around.
Those claws look awfully sharp.
The empty bag proves useless here.
Too late!
THAT won't help Graham against this huge beast!
It won't sway the cat. Graham's in trouble!
Don't bother the cat with THAT!

Graham wisely decides to keep his mouth shut.
Graham should know better than to keep things bottled up inside!
Many rocky islets dot the ocean just off-shore of the mountainous mainland.
Cedric keeps his eye on Graham while perched on a nearby tree branch.
Cedric keeps an eye on Graham near the town bakehouse.
Cedric waits for Graham in a nearby tree.
Cedric perches nervously on a tree limb at the edge of a gloomy forest.
Impatiently, Cedric watches Graham from the gnomes' roof.
Not being much of a honey eater, Cedric shows little interest in the beehive.
Cedric perches safely on a scrubby bush above the anthill and watches the activity below.
Cedric perches upon the "Swarthy Hog Inn" sign.
Even Cedric looks cold as he watches Graham traverse the icy path.
Shivering with the cold, Cedric seems to be a bit befuddled, and not much help.
Shivering with the cold, Cedric looks more than ready to leave these frozen reaches behind.
Cedric looks relieved to be out of those cold mountains.
Cedric looks with wonder at the beautiful beach.
Cedric seems as curious about this place as Graham.
Cedric looks frightened at the sight of the stone serpents.
Cedric looks more and more frightened the closer he and Graham get to the bizarre castle.
Cedric perches nervously as he surveys the surrounding area.
Impatiently, Cedric waits for Graham.
Cedric is too busy looking around and doesn't seem to be paying attention to Graham at the moment.
Cedric seems to be thinking big thoughts right now, perhaps planning their next move, and so is not in a talkative mood.
Having other things on his mind, Cedric doesn't appear to be in the mood to talk right now.
Cedric seems to be quietly contemplating their current situation, and so is not inclined to indulge in coversation right now.
Graham gently carries his friend Cedric, who has been wounded by the horrible harpies.
King Graham, heavy of heart, searches far and wide for his beloved family who've been stolen by an evil wizard.
It is a tiny brass key.
Mmmmmm. The custard pie looks delicious!
This is a large golden needle.
It is but a common silver coin.
Whew! This smelly old fish is disgusting!
This is an old, tarnished brass bottle.
The jeweled staff is obviously the work of an expert craftsman.
The worn old shoe is cracked and dry from the desert sun.
The small heart is made of pure gold.
It is a small harp of beautifully carved mahogany.
It is a shiny gold coin.
The craftsmanship of the marionette is superb.
The small leather pouch is drawn tightly closed.

column5: The pouch is empty.

The pair of sparkling emeralds dazzle the eyes.
The sparkling emerald dazzles the eyes.

It appears to be an average stick of wood.
Honey drips at the edges of the honeycomb chunk.
Graham carries a softened lump of beeswax.
This is a large, mouthwatering leg of lamb.
This is a left-over, half leg of lamb.
A good strong rope is a handy item to have!
The brilliant crystal shard feels smooth in Graham's hands.
A cobbler would normally use this small hammer to make shoes.
Graham can almost hear the ocean inside the spiral shell of the conch.
The bag is full of round, dried peas.
Graham carries a large empty bag, once occupied by dried peas.
It is a lovely golden locket on a delicate chain.
This fine cloak is thick and warm.
The amulet is attached to a soft leather thong.
The amulet glows softly with a power of its own.
The old wand doesn't seem to have any vitality left in it.
Crispin's wand glows brightly with renewed power.
This is a small, well-crafted sled.
The heavy iron bar is a bit rusted from being out in the weather.
This is a rusted old fishhook.
This is the finest pair of shoes Graham has ever seen, although a bit small for his feet.
It is an ordinary tambourine.
Mordack's wand glows brightly with restrained power.
Mordack's wand doesn't seem to have much life left in it.
The hairpin is made of a carved piece of bone with a sharp metal clip attached to it.
Poor Cedric is hurt and needs help. How can Graham help him?
Upon opening the leather pouch, Graham discovers three sparkling emeralds.
The pouch is already open.
Upon opening the locket, Graham sees a portrait of an older couple in regal attire. So as not to damage the picture, he quickly closes it again.
Graham waves Crispin's wand which now pulsates with renewed power, but nothing happens.
Graham gives the wand a good shake, but it only fizzles and dies.
Having learned to play the harp long ago, Graham now plays beautifully.
Graham is already wearing the warm cloak.
Here, the air is too warm to be wearing heavy outer garments.
Graham hits and shakes the tambourine with much ruckus, but finds it doesn't accomplish anything.
Graham has no desire to put the dirty honeycomb in his mouth no matter how tempting the honey may be!
Mmmmmmm! That was the best custard pie Graham has ever eaten!
Graham finds the leg of lamb a bit tough, but tasty enough. Filling up quickly, he saves the other half for later.
Feeling a bit hungry, Graham finishes off the other half of the leg of lamb.
Graham is already wearing the amulet around his neck.
The magic amulet begins to glow softly as Graham slips it over his head. He then carefully tucks the amulet into the front of his tunic, hiding it from sight.
The moldy cheese is not fit for eating.
Unfortunately Graham is all thumbs when it comes to operating a spinning wheel.
Even though these are a very fine pair of shoes, Graham finds them too small for his own feet.
Graham is too old to play with toys!
Nothing would be accomplished by using the hammer here.
Wearing the delicate locket would detract from Graham's "manly" appearance.
Graham would look silly wearing that hairpin!
Wearing one old shoe would do Graham no good at all!
The lump of beeswax has become soft and sticky from the warmth of Graham's body.
The smelly old fish is much too disgusting for human consumption.
Graham waves Mordack's glowing wand...but nothing happens. Could it be that Crispin was right? That wands only respond to their owner...like a pet?
Cedric is in too much pain to carry on a conversation right now.
Talking to yourself again, Graham?
Thanks for playing King's Quest V.
You cannot save a game right now.
You cannot restore a game right now.
Curious, Graham gazes down into Crispin's well, but sees nothing of interest.
The hand-hewn, wooden door is recessed within a small porch.
Thick-paned windows adorn the small house. It is difficult to see through them.
Nestled among the trees of the forest sits the wizard Crispin's worn, but cozy, cottage.
A small well is located near the cottage.
An unusual ornament decorates Crispin's front yard. Crispin being a wizard, it must have some magical significance which Graham could never understand.
A tiny pond adds charm to Crispin's forested home.
A small cellar door is located under the house.
A rustic stone bridge crosses the pond below Crispin's house.
The door to Crispin's house is now locked.
A worn dirt path wanders through a thick wood alive with the sound of many creatures. Between the trees, to the east, Graham can see the outline of a great mountain range.
A large, venomous snake blocks Graham's passage to the east.
Graham hits and shakes the tambourine with much ruckus, but finds it doesn't accomplish anything.
That won't convince the snake to leave.
In silence, the large serpent eyes Graham menacingly.
Having entered the warm valley awhile back, Graham has removed his uncomfortably heavy cloak.
That wasn't wise, Graham! He who speaks with forked tongue should never be trusted.
Too bad! Graham's swimming skills were no match for the mighty river.
The quaint little town of Serenia nestles at the base of a great snowcapped mountain range which rises sharply to the east.
A wild river tumbles down from the eastern mountains and flows swiftly below the small town.
Any journey across the great mountains promises to be very perilous indeed.
A rutted road leads into the town from the west while a smaller path joins it from the north.
A small tributary of the larger river powers an old waterwheel as it flows through the town.
Secure within a small pen, a spotted cow quietly chews her cud.
Cedric waits for Graham just outside the small town.
Unfortunately, the cow doesn't have anything to say. Her mouth is too full of cud.
Inside the barrel, Graham sees an old rotting fish.
The inside of the barrel is now quite empty.
Quaint houses and little shops line the town's main cobblestoned street.
A broken wagon blocks access to a smaller side street.
A prosperous-looking tailorshop occupies the town's main corner.
A small toyshop fronts the town's cobblestone street.
Nearly hidden at the end of the street sits a small shoeshop.
While blocking an alleyway, a frustrated man fixes a broken wheel on his wagon.
Graham notices an old wooden barrel on the street corner.
The town is busy with people going about their daily chores.
Graham notices a shiny silver coin lying forgotten on the street near the broken wagon.
Graham leans way down into the barrel and removes...phew!...the smelly old fish.
Graham could never carry around a big barrel.
The cart is too heavy for Graham to move by himself.
Suddenly, frantic squeakings alert Graham to a mangy cat chasing a terrified rat.
The cold river courses swiftly by the town bakehouse
A rutted, dirt road travels east and west beside the rushing river.
Thick, multipaned windows surround the bakehouse.
Graham spies a huge pile of logs to fuel the bakehouse ovens.
With a fine view of the rushing river, the bakehouse sits a bit out of town along an old, rutted road.
The bakehouse door beckons to all hungry travelers.
Pouncing, the scroungy cat catches a large, grey rat in its wicked claws.
Too late! The poor rat is already in the clutches of the wily cat who now runs quickly away.
Graham could never catch this mangy cat and wouldn't want to.
Graham feels the eyes of many creatures upon him as he follows a meandering path through the thick wood.
In a nearby tree trunk, an old wound has created a perfect birdbath.
Upon a fallen log sits a dashing young prince who looks very sad and confused.
What a wonderful bluebird. It could almost make Graham happy again if it wasn't for his family.
There's nothing in the tree but a little water.
Despite his own troubles, Graham feels sorry for the young man who obviously has troubles of his own.
Graham could never catch the bluebird.
The young prince is too despondent over something to even notice it.
The bluebird doesn't care about it.
The bluebird is too busy taking a bath to answer Graham.
The wide dirt path ends at a crude warning sign placed before an ominous-looking forest. Beyond the sign, the path narrows to nothing more than a root-ensnarled trail.
The sign seems self-explanatory enough: ENTER AT YOUR OWN RISK!
Beyond the warning sign, the gnarled trees seem to close in, entangling and confusing all who dare enter here.
An old, hollow log lies in a small clearing before the gloomy forest.
The old log doesn't look interesting enough to bother with.
The entrance to the elves' tunnel is left exposed.
A lovely little pond surrounds the base of a beautiful weeping willow tree.
There is a small pond here near the edge of a dark forest.
To the north, Graham can see the gnarly edge of a deep, dark forest.

A beautiful harp lies on the ground near the small pond.
The entrance to the small house is through a crudely-constructed door.
A small, shuttered window fronts the gnome house.
Utilizing fallen logs, a gnome has built himself a little forest home.
A young gnome happily plays with an exquisite marionette.

Graham can see a small pond in the distance to the north.

The young gnome is more interested in his marionette than in Graham.

Graham notices a huge anthill in the distance to the north.
A large bear seems to be very interested in the honey inside the old tree.
Graham notices a large stick lying on the ground near the old tree.

Graham bends down and picks up the large stick from the ground.

It looks like something may be after him.
All around him, Graham sees nothing but more desert. How much farther can he go on? Thankfully, though, a nearby pool of water can relieve Graham's overwhelming thirst.

An old shoe lies, forgotten, near the poor skeleton.
A rope and water basket sit near a small well.
A small oasis! Its tantalizing water, so sparkling in the desert sun! Graham's hot, thirsty body is irresistibly drawn to it.
Ah! Life-giving water! Nectar of the gods! Graham can now feel strength and renewal flowing through him.
Graham can't do much to help the poor man now...and vice versa!
Since Graham has just taken a drink, he's not thirsty at the moment.
Well, it's too late for conversation now!

DYING for a drink, Graham?

Graham should avoid the bandit at all costs!

Quickly, Graham grabs the old brass bottle.
Hurry! The exit door is about to close!
Cheer up, Graham. At least you can practice your game of tiddlywinks!

Ensnarling roots, creeping vines, decaying logs, and twisted, gnarled trees...the close feeling of the gloomy forest quickly overwhelms Graham.

There seems to be an unusually large number of toads in this forest.

A crude little door has been built into the trunk of this large, grotesque tree.

There is nothing else inside the little door of the tree.
Oh, oh! Watch out for those drop-offs Graham!

The path seems to dwindle down to nothing as it nears the strange structure.
Spitting hot steam and flames, a deep crevasse surrounds the strange little house.
A small door fronts the odd structure.
The dark forest seems to encase the witch's bizarre little house like a claustrophobic shroud.
A set of stone steps, much to narrow for Graham's larger body, wind precariously upward in the back of the room.
Graham spies a small drawer built into the trunk of a tree which pokes awkwardly through the wall of the house.
The old witch's house has been crudely fashioned from an old tree trunk and salvaged stone. Being cold and creepy, Graham finds he would just as soon hurry up and leave.
Tucked under a large crack in the wall which seems to serve as a window, Graham sees an interesting wooden trunk.
A small, intricate spinning wheel is put away in the trunk.
An interesting incense burner hangs from a protruding tree branch. Occasionally, from within it, a tiny glint winks.
An interesting incense burner hangs from a protruding tree branch.
A small leather pouch is tucked away in the drawer.
Reaching a hand into the trunk, Graham retrieves the small spinning wheel.
The winding steps are much too narrow for Graham to ever fit through.
There is nothing else inside the drawer.
The trunk is now empty.
The incense burner is now empty.
From here, the narrow rocky path leads east and south through the gloomy forest.
Strange plants and animals inhabit this dark and dreary place while thin rays of sunlight barely break the surface of the forest's thick foliage.
Peering curiously at him through the heavy foliage of the dark forest, Graham notices several pairs of bright, blinking eyes.
A sticky puddle of honey lies on the ground.
A large rock-like creature blocks further passage to the west.
Rocky has moved aside to allow Graham passage through the forest.
Graham can plainly SEE the eyes, but he can't quite reach them through the thick foliage.
The rock-like creature is not inclined to move farther.
This situation seems to require very careful thought. Graham needs to spend more time on this.

Graham squeezes the honeycomb as hard as he can, which causes the honey to drip out of it onto the ground creating a sticky little "puddle" at his feet. Now all that's left of the honeycomb is a piece of beeswax, which Graham puts back in his pocket.
Graham decides to wait until he sees a good reason to toss away these fine emeralds.
The small creatures, whoever they are, don't seem to be interested in it.
Graham receives no answer.
Whoever is watching Graham is unwilling to indulge in any conversation.
Rocky isn't talking anymore.
A path, tangled with roots and vines, leads to the north and east through the dense foliage of the dark forest.
Unseen eyes seem to watch Graham as he stumbles confusedly through the thick maze of the gloomy forest.
A root-rutted path stumbles its way east, west, and north through the dark and gloomy forest.
Through the mists of the forest, Graham can barely see a small, house-like form to the north.
The dark forest seems to close in on Graham as he tentatively makes his way through it.
Narrowing to the west, the dirt road widens as it heads eastward.
The brisk river rushes swiftly by the quaint country inn.
A large haystack dominates the area in front of the barn.
An old, uninteresting barn is located behind the country inn.
Just off a rutted dirt road, a country inn overlooks the picturesque rushing river.
Weary travelers can enter through the inn's front door.
This is a side entrance of the country inn.
The side door is locked.
Graham can see an unbreakable padlock on the barn door.
Graham watches with surprise as a contingent of ants marches into the haystack and begins to swarm through it.
Carefully, Graham searches through the haystack but doesn't see anything of importance.
The key won't fit this lock.

There is nothing else of interest inside the cupboard.
Inside the cupboard, Graham sees a large, juicy leg of lamb.
Graham looks around the inn's kitchen and finds it rather sparse and untidy.
It appears that the door leads outside.
The sound of men talking and laughing loudly floats through this door.
In the corner of the room, Graham spies a large kitchen cupboard.
Graham begins to shiver at the sudden drop in temperature.
Oh, oh! That last step was a doozy!

Sheer, vertical cliffs plummet dizzyingly downward from the edge of the frozen path.
Graham dons his warm cloak for protection against the freezing mountain air.
Graham needs warmth, not this!
Graham begins to shiver violently at the extreme cold of these upper reaches while his hands and face begin to numb. He can barely muster the strength to go on.
Graham notices his stomach beginning to rumble with hunger from the exertion of the mountain climb.
Well Graham, how does it feel to be a "Pop"...sicle?
A frozen waterfall hinders Graham's progress as in the warmer seasons it had washed away part of the path on which he is currently travelling.
Looking upwards, Graham can see a snowy ledge above the steep cliff next to him.
Graham sees another possible route through the mountains from the ledge above him.
If only he could reach it...!
Graham notices a rock overhang near an upper ledge. A rope hangs precariously from it.
Graham notices a rock overhang near an upper ledge.

The remains of an old tree poke out of the mountainside near an upper ledge.
Graham's rope hangs dangerously from a rocky overhang.
The rope dangles precariously from a protruding tree branch.
The icy cliff is much too steep for Graham to climb without help.
Hmmm. The rocky overhang catches Graham's interest...
Well, the tree branch looks interesting...
Whoops! That was a fatal step!
As with the path below, the now-frozen waterfall has also washed away parts of this upper trail which narrowly skirts the mountain edge and then heads off to the east.
Graham can see tempting rock outcroppings protruding from the frozen waterfall.
An old log has fallen precariously across a washed-out portion of the narrow trail.
Graham's rope dangles down from a rocky overhang to the path below.
The snowy path abruptly ends where a gradual slope continues eastward.
The shape of one particular mountaintop seems vaguely familiar to Graham.
Graham can see a breathtaking view of distant snow-covered mountains towering majestically above a beautiful valley with a ribbon of river slicing through it.
It won't help Graham cross the icy crevasse.
Well Graham, remember when you turned down that last meal at home...?
Graham's hunger grows acute. Without food, he may soon die.
A snowy path zigzags its way across the top of a narrow ridge toward a deep crevasse.
From here, the path widens and continues on to the east.
A deep crevasse splits the snowy mountain ridge in two while a thin strip of ice crosses it. Unfortunately, it looks too wide to jump across.
In the distance, snowy mountains loom above a lovely river valley.
Graham's sled lies in several broken pieces on the eastern side of the icy crevasse.
Graham thinks about attempting to jump across the crevasse, but wisely chooses not to.
The broken sled is now no good to anybody.
Perhaps with some momentum Graham could use this to cross the crevasse.
It won't help Graham cross the crevasse.

A castle, buried in snow and ice, perches precariously atop a steep pinnacle.
A shivering eagle perches weakly upon a small rock. Despite his own problems, Graham's heart goes out to the poor thing.
The poor eagle gives Graham a pitiful look. Graham would like to help him...but how?
That won't help the poor eagle.
The eagle appears to be too weak to indulge in any further conversation.
